repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency Electric
            Power Reconstruction Project and Second Electric Power
            Reconstruction  Project

abstracts.cdata!:
These are the first projects in the
            Bank's substantial portfolio to be evaluated by OED
            since lending operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina began in
            1996. Sixteen of these projects were processed as
            'emergency' operations, one of which is the
            subject of this evaluation The only previous OED report on
            the country to date is a case study of post- conflict
            reconstruction, published in 2000, but based on fieldwork
            carried out in 1997. The Emergency Electric Power
            Reconstruction Project has had a highly satisfactory overall
            outcome. Project sustainability is assessed as likely, while
            the institutional development impact was substantial. Bank
            and borrower performance during the project are rated as
            highly satisfactory because rapid and efficient
            implementation by both the Bank and borrower staff meant
            that the project was completed and fully disbursed only
            three years from identification. The outcome of the Second
            Electric Power Reconstruction Project is rated as
            satisfactory and the project's sustainability as
            likely. The institutional development impact of the project
            is rated as substantial, because of the progress recorded in
            bringing staff from the three utilities to work together on
            common is- sues, especially power trading, and in raising
            awareness of the importance of the environ- mental aspects
            of power generation. Bank and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. The key finding from these projects is that
            when electricity supply cannot be organized in a manner that
            is technically and economically optimal, there are high
            costs to a country in terms of lost efficiency and economies
            of scale. The project experience offers two lessons: 1)
            Power sector restructuring in a heavily coal-based power
            system cannot be delinked from reform of the coal industry
            because of the predominance of coal in the cost of producing
            electricity from it. Reforms in both sectors should be
            addressed in parallel, or preferably coal sector reforms
            should precede electricity, but not lag behind. 2)
            Experience with tariff increases and improved revenue
            collection in the immediate aftermath of the peace accord
            shows that consumers are willing to contribute to the cost
            of the rapid restoration of electricity supply.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Second Electric
            Power Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory
            with project sustainability, likely. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory overall. Lessons
            learned consisted of the following: Too many contracts lead
            to an excessive supervision workload. Three governments,
            three implementing agencies, and many parallel financiers
            also lead to a large preparation and supervision workload.
            In this case, the number of parallel financiers enlisted
            under the project proved cumbersome, given the very variable
            levels of commitment and supervision of parallel financed
            components. Lastly, where there are multiple sector
            institutions with diverse, and sometimes conflicting,
            interests and priorities, the establishment of formal
            structures for collaboration, such as the Joint Power
            Coordination Center, can contribute significantly to greater
            cooperation and harmony between the various institutions.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Second Electric
            Power Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the Second
            Electric Power Reconstruction Project is to restore electric
            power supply at least cost.  The project will help to
            restore the generation, transmission and distribution
            systems to meet at least part of the expect increase in
            demand within Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), reconnect many
            consumers still without power after the war, and reduce
            power outages, variations in voltage level, and other
            quality of service defects.  The secondary object is to
            improve cost recovery.  The project components include: (a)
            rehabilitation of the hydropower stations of Rama, Jajce 1,
            Caplijina, Trebinje 1 and 2, and Bocac; and the coal-fired
            power stations of Tuzla (Second Phase), Kakanj (Second
            Phase), Gacko, and Uglejvik; (b) rehabilitation of
            transmission facilities in the Federation, Republika Srpska,
            and between them; (c) reconstruction and rehabilitation of
            distribution networks in the Federation and Republika
            Srpska; (d) rehabilitation of coal mines associated with the
            coal power stations of Tuzla, Kakanj, Gacko, and Uglejvik;
            and (e) technical assistance consisting of a transmission
            and institutional rehabilitation study, a coal sector
            restructuring study, and engineering and project management support.
